Another project sunset retrospective, this time a web SPA Mastodon client: https://nolanlawson.com/2023/01/09/retiring-pinafore/

Lots of good learning here from @nolan including the challenge of build an offline-friendly app against REST APIs and federated unreliable servers. And the difference between ActivityPub and Mastondon’s native API.

But very cool that it will keep being available indefinitely thanks to static HTML hosting!

Every few months, I find myself recommending basically everyone read this one article about the protactile deafblind language. But particularly relevant to mastodon users (AND people working on automated image captioning) is its great discussion of what makes good alt text.

There is such a thing as excess detail! It may make you look like a True Ally, but you're not helping blind people. #screenreaders #accessibility

https://audio.mcsweeneys.net/transcripts/against_access.html

title: Microsoft’s new AI can simulate anyone’s voice with 3 seconds of audio

last_post.content:
Nothing to see here. Move along.

"Microsoft researchers announced a new text-to-speech AI model called VALL-E that can closely simulate a person's voice when given a three-second audio sample. Once it learns a specific voice, VALL-E can synthesize audio of that person saying anything—and do it in a way that attempts to preserve the speaker's emotional tone."

https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/01/microsofts-new-ai-can-simulate-anyones-voice-with-3-seconds-of-audio/

Crazy dataset you encounter infrequently—from Bank of England's "millenium of macroeconomic data." @kjhealy calls it, "Escaping the Malthusian trap"—animation of England's compared w/ estimates of GDP per capita; runs from 1270 to current times (2016). Caveats notwithstanding (where to begin?😂 ), shows largely positive impacts of technology, advances in societal/economic organization (incl. capitalism) & plague's adverse impact. https://kieranhealy.org/blog/archives/2023/01/08/escaping-the-malthusian-trap/
#dataviz #economics#development #progress

title: Company using ChatGPT for mental health support raises ethical issues

last_post.content:
I don't even know where to start with this one. Apparently the mental health service kokocares.org ran a multi-day trial on 4000 users without their informed consent, in which koko's "peer supporters" used ChatGPT to craft their responses to the people they were providing with mental health support.

https://www.businessinsider.com/company-using-chatgpt-mental-health-support-ethical-issues-2023-1

Just (re)discovered Casey Greene's super "preprint similarity search tool". It did a great job for our recent #preprint. It uses a language learning model to find like #publications to help you pick your target #journals.

https://greenelab.github.io/preprint-similarity-search/

I'm teaching "NLP for Cultural Analytics" at UW Linguistics this quarter, and I thought I'd share my reading list for the course.

https://maria-antoniak.github.io/teaching/2023-nlp-ca

Lots of usual suspects from the Journal of Cultural Analytics, but also pieces from NLP and computational social science. Thinking back to an earlier thread on "what even is cultural analytics," you can see from this list my perception of the field (or maybe just what I'm in the mood to read right now).

#DigitalHumanities #CulturalAnalytics

title: Furby 1998 source code : David Hampton, Wayne Schulz : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The Furby source code is public and heavily commented. For example, it turns the microphone off when the motors are running.

Furby was the 1998 version of ChatGPT and tons of people thought it actually slowly learned English words. The NSA was alarmed. However it turned out the "learning" process was just on a timer and the "microphone" only triggers on loud sounds.
https://archive.org/details/furby-source

last_post.content: There's a whole cottage industry right now looking at the limits of #ChatGPT (e.g. it can't double-check claims or do external attribution) and turning those limits into sentences that begin "Language models can only ever ..." I get why this is a reassuring, widely circulated message, but I wish a few people circulating it would mention that there is already active research that seeks to address those limits. https://paperswithcode.com/paper/attributed-question-answering-evaluation-and

If you're into retrocomputing stop what you're doing and check out Medley Interlisp, a restoration of the software environment of Xerox Lisp Machines rehosted on modern systems.

It's the most fascinating and advanced software development environment I've ever seen. I posted about my first impressions, why I love Medley Interlisp, and how I plan to use it:

https://journal.paoloamoroso.com/my-encounter-with-medley-interlisp

#interlisp #LispMachines #lisp #retrocomputing

title: Join the Actions for Obsidian beta

last_post.content:
I work on an app called Actions for Obsidian. It's the missing link between #macOS and #Obsidian: it adds 30+ actions to Apple Shortcuts for a deeper Obs integration into macOS (and later, iOS).

I think you'll like it.

A few spots on the current beta just opened up: https://testflight.apple.com/join/CPFTNadV It's not feature complete yet but I'm happy enough with my progress to have more people give it a go.

For progress updates, check out https://obsidian.actions.work

(Boost very much welcome 😉)

If you're at #GROUP2023, please say hi to Jessica Wang, a former masters student at MIT, who will be presenting our work "Designing for Engaging with News using Moral Framing towards Bridging Ideological Divides" on Wed! We looked at the impact of surfacing moral framing in online discussions about news on contentious topics, finding in a small scale study that it helped people consider how to frame their own arguments in the moral values of the opposing side.

#Quintessence has changed to become even better. Now it's a client-side web utility (quintsns.pianeta.uno) that sorts through your Mastodon timeline to find frequently-boosted links. The new version has titles for the links! It can be a little slow, but it does what I want an algorithmic timeline to do: https://mastodon.uno/@quintsns/109654684719390716

The Chronocyclegraph was developed by Frank Gilbreth and his wife, Lillian in the early 20th century. The couple employed small lamps on worker's hands and time-lapse photography to reduce a work cycle to the most efficient sequence. Gilbreth was the first to propose that a nurse could assist the surgeon, by handing them surgical instruments. He also devised the techniques used to teach how to rapidly disassemble and reassemble weapons.

https://we-make-money-not-art.com/the_chronocyclegraph/

title: GitHub - rougier/book-mode: A clean interface for org files (Emacs)

last_post.content: #emacs Book mode is an attempt at offering an interface for reading org-mode files with a clean layout. It is based on the use of large margins, headline and mode-line, with leading stars and bullets in the left margin using right alignment and different symbols. All decorations are part of the header-line (including upper left colored part and right upper glyph) and messages are displayed in the mode-line. Code at https://github.com/rougier/book-mode

title: China, a Pioneer in Regulating Algorithms, Turns Its Focus to Deepfakes

last_post.content:
China is pushing ahead in regulating deepfakes and generative AI.

New rules on Tuesday will ban the use of AI-generated content for spreading "fake news”—and require providers of “deep synthesis” technologies to visibly label content that looks real.

While the former bucks international norms, the latter follows them.

People should observe what happens, @gwbstr said.

https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-a-pioneer-in-regulating-algorithms-turns-its-focus-to-deepfakes-11673149283

The journal Meta-Psychology envisions a radically open way to publish.

It is free to publish in, open access, open peer review. Data and materials are required to be made publicly available. All statistical analyses are reproduced by their team to ensure reproducibility. They allow "evolving papers" where updates, replications, commentaries are added as links in the original paper webpage.

https://open.lnu.se/index.php/metapsychology/index
#OpenScience #Science @academicchatter #AcademicChatter #AcademicPublishing

My latest in Puck on #TikTok & a possible ban:

"It’s risky to build on someone else’s property. Ownership of our data, social graph, and financial relationships has great value. How many times do we have to lose our followers on a social network to realize they were never ours? Unless we have a way to reach them outside the walled garden, such as an email address, mobile number, or credit card number, then they belong to the garden, not to us. We’re just sharecroppers."

https://puck.news/tiktok-on-the-clock/

Visual cortex is affected by sounds. Does this mean it is multisensory? Does it represent sounds?

Today in Nature #Neuroscience (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41593-022-01227-x) Célian Bimbard and team find otherwise.

Sound-evoked activity in visual cortex was similar across neurons. Even neurons in hippocampus. It persisted after we cut fibers from auditory cortex!

This activity was predicted by… subtle body movements evoked by the sounds. It reflects brainwide state and behavior signals.

#NeuroNewPaper

title: Nature announces support for authors from over 70 countries to publish open access | Corporate Affairs Homepage | Springer Nature

last_post.content:
From today, research papers accepted-in-principle (the step before formal accept) in Nature or one of the Nature research journals (e.g., Nature Chemistry) from corresponding authors based in countries classified by the World Bank as low-income (LIC) or lower-middle-income economies (LMICs) can be published gold open access at no cost.

#OpenAccess #OpenScience

https://group.springernature.com/gp/group/media/press-releases/nature-announces-support-for-authors-to-publish-open-access/23894926

I don't know anything about this instance or its community, but I like this section of its About page. It feels like a human being talking about what they're willing to do for other humans.
The way corporate platforms communicate (or fail to) has really skewed our understandings of what kinds of relationships we get into with them. Human communication like this feels like it's recalibrating that a bit, to something better and more like a future I'd like to live in.
https://artistalley.space/about

It’s January 9, and I just read the best article I will read all month.

“Social Quitting” by @pluralistic

“Once a platform has its users and business customers locked in, it can enshittify its service to the point of near uselessness without losing either, allocating all the useful surplus in the business to its shareholders.”

“The important thing about the Fediverse isn’t that it’s noncommercial or decentralized—it’s that its design impedes surplus harvesting.”

https://doctorow.medium.com/social-quitting-f049b33ad3f6

title: A.I. Turns Its Artistry to Creating New Human Proteins

last_post.content:
The NYT continues to be trash at covering so-called "AI" (or, in NYT style sheet "A.I.").

This piece is framed as though the folks working on protein folding "took inspiration" from DALL-E & the like:

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/09/science/artificial-intelligence-proteins.html

No, "A.I." doesn't have "artistry". And no the biologists didn't look at all the synthetic images on social media being passed around as "AI art" and say "hey, let's do that for proteins!"

Here are two growing #OpenScience projects that I'm enjoying - might be useful for others..?

https://openalex.org/

Active development of an open index of papers, authors and citations - API is already amazing and website updates appear to be coming soon... (eg see my profile here: https://explore.openalex.org/authors/A2499239453)

https://forrt.org/

Framework for Open and Reproducible Research Training - practical and detailed resources for integrating open and reproducible science into uni-level teaching.

We are excited to announce that Cognitive Computational Neuroscience (CCN) 2023 will take place this year in Oxford from August 24 - 27, 2023. The conference will take place at the Examination Schools – more information can be found here:
www.venues.ox.ac.uk/our-venues/examination-schools/.

–
Confirmed speakers for this year's CCN include Stan Dehaene, Helen Barron, Cate Hartley, Jay McClelland and Tim Kietzmann TimKietzmann@neuromatch.social

–

We also want to note that the paper submission period will be earlier this year than in previous years: abstract submissions will open end of January, and will close March 31.

—

For the most up-to-date information about CCN 2023, including reminders about deadlines, join our mailing list (https://mail.securecms.com/mailman/listinfo/ccneuro-announce) and also follow us here on Twitter (https://twitter.com/CogCompNeuro) or Mastodon (https://mastodon.social/@CogCompNeuro@qoto.org)

Please boost!!
